title: UC Davis variety recommendations
author: Paul M. Vossen and Deborah Silva
note: the same tables are reproduced in individual PDFs and also in the California Master Gardener Handbook (2015)

categories.name: early summer
categories.note: These cultivars do not have the high-quality characteristics of standard cultivars but ripen early when no other fresh apples are available. They are good for eating fresh and cooking.

categories.name: disease resistant
categories.note: Several scab-resistant apple cultivars have been developed in breeding programs for the eastern United States, where this disease is quite sever due to summer humidity and rain. Some have received limited testing under California growing conditions. In growing districts with extended spring rains, organic growers should experiment with these cultivars to see how they perform in their orchards.

plants.name: Fuji
plants.note: Round to flat apple with very sweet yellow-orange flesh. Skin is red if given enough sunlight and cool temperatures. One of the best sweet eating apples. Stores well.

plants.name: Gala
plants.note: Small to medium sized, conic red apple with excellent flavor and keeping qualities. The best cultivar for the early season.

plants.name: Gravenstein
plants.note: Medium-large fruit with short, fat stem. Skin is greenish yellow overlaid with red stripes. Excellent flavor when fully ripe. Crisp, subacid, and aromatic. A good sauce and pie apple. Stores and ships poorly. High percentage of windfalls. Sterile pollen.

plants.name: Golden Delicous
plants.note: Conic apple with a long stem, yellow to green skin, yellow flesh, and russet dots. Sweet, juicy, fine textured. Number one on the California North Coast for fresh eating quality and processing. Stores well but susceptible to bitter pit, bruising, russeting. Erratic in self-fruitfulness.

plants.name: Granny Smith
plants.note: Round, green to yellow-skinned apple that is quite firm. Keeps very well. Crisp flesh. If harvested early, it is green and tart. Late-harvested fruit are yellow and sweet.

plants.name: Jonathan
plants.note: Round, red apple with pure white flesh. Crisp, juicy, and slightly subacid. Excellent for eating fresh, sauce, and juice. Highly susceptible to mildew, fire blight, and Jonathan spot.

plants.name: Red Delicious
plants.note: Conic apple with tapered base and five distinct lobes. Skin color varies from solid red to a mixture of red and green stripes. Crisp, sweet, mid-flavored yellow flesh. Many strains. Best used fresh. Stores well

plants.name: Rome Beauty
plants.note: Round fruit with a deep cavity, no lobes, and little russet. Several strains, including the old standard and several new strains with solid red skin, such as Taylor and Law. Stores moderately well. Tree leafs out late, flowers late, and produces flowers and fruit on long spur growth that requires modification in pruning. Good for baking.

plants.category_note: Strains (mutations) of the original cultivars that have shorter internodes and are naturally dwarfing. Best on seedling rootstock.
These cultivars are adapted to the low latitudes of southern California because they have low winter chilling requirements (< 300 hours).

These cultivars do well in much of California if there is adequate chilling and summer heat is not too intense. They are hard to find because they lack commercial value. Many have excellent flavor and perform well in home gardens.

plants.name: Akane
plants.note: Similar to Jonathan but earlier, good solid red color, white flesh, good for eating fresh and juice.

plants.name: Jerseymac
plants.note: Large, good red color, excellent flavor, firmer than McIntosh, stores 4 to 8 weeks.

plants.name: Jonamac
plants.note: Similar to McIntosh but has better color, firmness, and storage life.

plants.name: Paulared
plants.note: High-quality, white flesh, stores fairly well, tree requires thinning.

plants.name: Vista Bell
plants.note: Terminal bearing habit, white-fleshed fruit, stores well.

plants.name: Enterprise
plants.note: A large-fruited, late-maturing, dense, crisp cultivar that has good keeping qualities. The skin is dark red over a yellow-green background. One of the best of the scab-resistant cultivars.

plants.name: Florina
plants.note: A promising scab-resistant selection from France, with large, round oblong, purple-red fruit; ripens late and has a mixed sweet tart flavor.

plants.name: Freedom
plants.note: A late-season cultivar with large fruit and mild flavor; not completely immune to scab.

plants.name: Goldrush
plants.note: A scab-immune selection with Golden Delicious parentage; late maturing, large, firm textured, and tart with an excellent flavor; stores well.

plants.name: Jonafree
plants.note: A midseason apple that compares with Jonathan, with soft flesh and uneven coloring.

plants.name: Liberty
plants.note: One of the best-quality apples of the disease-resistant cultivars; is very productive and requires heavy early thinning to achieve good size; ripens in midseason, has an attractive red color with some striping, and a good, sweet flavor.

plants.name: Prima
plants.note: An early-season, uneven-ripening, moderate-quality cultivar.

plants.name: Priscilla
plants.note: A late-season cultivar with small fruit, soft flesh, and mild flavor.

plants.name: Pristine
plants.note: Moderate to large, tart, yellow apple immune to scab and resistant to fire blight and mildew.

plants.name: Red Free
plants.note: Matures in early July, heat-sensitive, small fruited; susceptible to water core, sunburn, and russet.

plants.name: Williams Pride
plants.note: Early maturing, scab immune; also resistant to fire blight and mildew; medium to large fruit with a round-oblique shape; attractive red striped color on a green-yellow background.

plants.name: Bartlett
plants.note: The best-quality pear fruit. Bell shaped with white flesh and excellent flavor. Tree is susceptible to fire blight. Fruit keep relatively well, up to 2 months after maturing in August. Sensation is a red Bartlett.

plants.name: Bosc
plants.note: Midseason cultivar that bears heavy crops regularly. Fruit are long and tapering, with a long neck and stem. Skin is golden russet brown.

plants.name: Comice
plants.note: Inconsistent bearer. Excellent fruit, green with red blush. Delicate skin, chubby shape. Very vigorous tree, does best on Quince rootstock. Late maturing.

plants.name: D’Anjou
plants.note: Good winter pear with excellent keeping qualities. A large, vigorous tree. Egg-shaped fruit with a small shoulder. Light green to yellow-green color with white flesh. French origin. There is a red strain called Red Anjou.

plants.name: Seckel
plants.note: The small fruit are reddish green, with very dense, sweet, flavorful flesh. Excellent quality for the home orchard. Resistant to fire blight and pear scab.

plants.name: Winter Nellis
plants.note: Medium small, almost round fruit with light russeting over a green skin. Resistant to blight. Large tree. Regular producer, but late.

plants.category_note: These pear cultivars are adapted to the low latitudes of southern California becuse they have low winter chilling requirements (< 300 hours).

plants.name: Chojuro
plants.note: Greenish brown to brown russet skin. Coarse, tasty flesh.

plants.name: Hosui
plants.note: Brown skin, juicy white flesh with a sweet aromatic flavor.

plants.name: Kikusui
plants.note: Yellow-green skin. White flesh, excellent flavor. Fruit drop from tree when ripe.

plants.name: Niiataka
plants.note: Very large, juicy fruit with an aromatic flavor.

plants.name: Nijisseiki
plants.note: Also known as Twentieth Century. Excellent quality. Very popular cultivar, yellow-green skin.

plants.name: Shinko
plants.note: Brown russet skin; firm, crisp flesh; very aromatic flavor.

plants.name: Shinseiki
plants.note: Amber yellow skin; White flesh is crisp but softens rapidly; less flavor than other cultivars.

plants.name: Tsu Li
plants.note: Blooms early. Use Ya Li as pollenizer. Chinese type (pear shape). Light green color, crisp, tasty flesh.

plants.name: Ya Li
plants.note: Blooms early. Use Tsu Li as pollenizer. Chinese type (pear shape). Light, shiny yellow color, crisp, tasty flesh.

plants.name: Ambrosia
plants.note: Huge fruit, pale pink skin; similar to Wonderful

plants.name: Eversweet
plants.note: Very sweet, almost seedless fruit. Red skin, clear juice. Good for coastal areas.

plants.name: Granada
plants.note: Deep crimson fruit color. Matures early but needs heat

plants.name: Ruby Red
plants.note: Matures late (with Wondeful) but not as sweet or colorful as Wonderful. All fruit matures at once.

plants.name: Wonderful
plants.note: Large, deep red fruit. Large, juicy, red kernels. Small seed. Matures late. Juice is made into grenadine syrup.

plants.name: Champion
plants.note: Green-yellow flesh. Pear-shaped fruit.

plants.name: Orange
plants.note: Orange-yellow flesh. Golden skin. Rich flavor. Low-chill cultivar.

plants.name: Pineapple
plants.note: The preferred cultivar. Pineapple flavor. White flesh. Golden skin. Low-chill fruit.

plants.name: Smyrna
plants.note: Large fruit with brown pubescence. Light, tender flesh. Yellow skin. Low-chill fruit.

plants.name: Van Deman
plants.note: Pale yellow, coarse flesh. Orange skin turns red when cooked.

plants.name: Autumn Royal
plants.note: Blenheim sport (mutation). Ripens in late summer to fall.

plants.name: Moorpark
plants.note: Excellent flavor, ripens unevenly, highly colored.

plants.name: Royal
plants.note: Large, very flavorful, used for eating fresh and drying.

plants.name: Tilton
plants.note: Large fruit, heavy producer. Mild flavor. Used for canning.

plants.category_note: These apricot cultivars are adapted to the low latitudes of southern California because they have low winter chilling requirements (< 300 hours).
These cultivars are newer and should be evaluated for your climate zone and site before being selected.

plants.name: Bing
plants.note: Industry standard. Deep mahogany red fruit. Produces very heavily. Very susceptible to bacterial canker. Pollenized by Van, Black tartarian, or Sam. Bing, Lambert, and Royal Ann will not pollinate each other (they are intrasterile).

plants.name: Black Tartarian
plants.note: Small, black fruit. A good pollenizer for Bing and most other cultivars.

plants.name: Brooks
plants.note: A large, dark red fruit with good flavor. Produces few doubles even in hot climates.

plants.name: Early Burlat
plants.note: Moderate-sized fruit. Ripens 2 weeks before Bing. Soft flesh. Pollenized by Bing and B. Tartarian.

plants.name: Early Ruby
plants.note: Early season. Large, dark fred fruit. Prolific. Fruit hold on tree.

plants.name: Lambert
plants.note: Dark, large, firm fruit. Pollenized by Van. Late season. Lambert, Bing, and Royal Ann do not pollinate each other.

plants.name: Rainier
plants.note: Yellow-red blush. Large, crack-resistant fruit.

plants.name: Royal Ann
plants.note: Yellow fruit with a red blush. Pollenized by Van. Late season, Royal Ann, Lambert, and Bing will not pollinate each other.

plants.name: Stella
plants.note: Dark-fleshed fruit. Matures just after Bing. Self-fruitful.

plants.name: Van
plants.note: Large, dark fruit. Pollenized by Bing or Lambert.

plants.name: Early Richmond
plants.note: Very early in season. Bright red fruit.

plants.name: Meteor
plants.note: Semidwarf.

plants.name: Montmorency
plants.note: The leadign sour cultivar. Medium-sized, dark red fruit.

plants.name: North Star
plants.note: Semidwarf. Self-fruitful.

plants.name: Arctic Glo
plants.note: Small, fantastic flavor. White flesh. Early.

plants.name: Fantasia
plants.note: Large, brightly-colored yellow freestone. Late.

plants.name: Flamekist
plants.note: Excellent quality. Large, firm, yellow, clingstone.

plants.name: Flavortop
plants.note: Large, excellent flavor. Yellow, freestone. Midseason.

plants.name: Goldmine
plants.note: Large, great flavor. White flesh. Freestone.

plants.name: Heavenly White
plants.note: Large, excellent flavor. White flesh.

plants.name: May Grand
plants.note: Large, yellow fruited, freestone. Early.

plants.name: Panamint
plants.note: Medium-sized fruit. Red skin, golden flesh. Freestone, low-chill cultivar.

plants.name: Red Gold
plants.note: Large, excellent flavor. Stores well. Late.

plants.name: Rose
plants.note: Old favorite white freestone with excellent flavor and low-chilling requirement.

plants.name: September Red
plants.note: Large, yellow. Very late.

plants.name: Snow Queen
plants.note: Early-season white freestone, juicy and tasty.

plants.name: Summer Grand
plants.note: One of the best. Large, yellow, freestone.

plants.category_note: These nectarine cultivars are adapted to the low latitudes of southern California because they have low winter chilling requirements.

plants.name: Autumn Gold
plants.note: Medium-large fruit. Yellow flesh. Keeps well.

plants.name: Babcock
plants.note: Medium sized. White flesh. Freestone, low-chill cultivar.

plants.name: Earligrande
plants.note: Excellent flavor. Yellow-red blush. Semifreestone, low-chill cultivar.

plants.name: Fairtime
plants.note: Large fruit. Yellow, firm flesh. Excellent flavor.

plants.name: Fay Elberta
plants.note: Large fruit. Yellow flesh. Freestone.

plants.name: Forty-Niner
plants.note: Large fruit. Yellow flesh. Freestone.

plants.name: Indian Blood
plants.note: Cling. Red skin and flesh. Tart. Prolific.

plants.name: La Feliciana
plants.note: Medium sized. Firm, red. Excellent flavor. Somewhat more disease resistant.

plants.name: Loring
plants.note: Very large fruit. Red skin. Yellow flesh. Freestone. Somewhat more disease resistant.

plants.name: Nectar
plants.note: White flesh. Pink skin. Excellent flavor.

plants.name: O’Henry
plants.note: One of the best. Large fruit. Yellow flesh. Freestone.

plants.name: Redhaven
plants.note: Yellow. Semifreestone. Needs heavy thinning.

plants.name: Rio Oso Gem
plants.note: Very large fruit. Yellow flesh. Freestone.

plants.name: Springcrest
plants.note: Medium sized. Yellow flesh. Semi-freestone.

plants.name: Suncrest
plants.note: Large fruit. Yellow flesh. Freestone. Midseason.

plants.name: Veteran
plants.note: Red blush. Elberta-type. Freestone. Dependable, heavy producer, excellent flavor. Somewhat more disease resistant.

plants.category_note: These peach cultivars are adapted to the low latitudes of southern California because they have low winter chilling requirements (< 300 hours).

plants.name: Autumn Rosa
plants.note: Large. Purple skin. Self-fertile. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Beauty
plants.note: Green skin, amber flesh, heart shaped. Poor keeper. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Burgundy
plants.note: Red skin and flesh. Self-fertile. Holds well.

plants.name: El Dorado
plants.note: Purple skin. Amber flesh. Large, oblong.

plants.name: Elephant Heart
plants.note: Purple skin. Large, heart shaped. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Friar
plants.note: Black skin. Firm, amber flesh. Mild flavor. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Golden Nectar
plants.note: Large. Yellow flesh. Tender skin. Great flavor. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Howard Wonder
plants.note: Large, pink skin. Yellow flesh. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Kelsey
plants.note: Green-yellow skin and flesh. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Laroda
plants.note: Red-purple skin. Yellow flesh.

plants.name: Mariposa
plants.note: Green-yellow skin. Red flesh. Large, heart shaped. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Nubiana
plants.note: Purple-black skin. Yellow flesh. Oblong. Japanese plum.

plants.name: President
plants.note: Large. Blue skin. Yellow flesh. European plum.

plants.name: Red Beauty
plants.note: Red skin, yellow flesh, excellent flavor.

plants.name: Roysum
plants.note: Light purple skin. Yellow flesh.

plants.name: Santa Rosa
plants.note: Purple skin. Amber flesh. Excellent flavor. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Satsuma
plants.note: Red skin and flesh. Small, round. Japanese plum.

plants.name: Shiro
plants.note: Light green–yellow skin. Yellow flesh.

plants.name: Simka
plants.note: Dark black skin. Yellow flesh. Oblong.

plants.name: Sprite Cherry Plum
plants.note: Black, sweet skin. Exotic flavor. Small.

plants.name: Wickson
plants.note: Green-yellow skin. Yellow flesh. Large, heart shaped. Japanese plum.

plants.category_note: These plum cultivars are adapted to the low latitudes of southern California because they have low winter chilling requirements.

plants.name: French
plants.note: Medium-sized fruit. Self-fertile. Late maturing. European plum.

plants.name: Green Gage
plants.note: Greenish yellow skin. Amber flesh. Old, European plum.

plants.name: Imperial
plants.note: Large fruit. Requires cross pollination. Late maturing. European plum.

plants.name: Italian
plants.note: Large fruit. Purple skin. Yellow flesh. European plum.

plants.name: Flavor King
plants.note: low chill

locations.Sierra Nevada Foothills: blank cell in the original chart

plants.name: Flavor Grenade
plants.note: low chill

plants.name: Flavor Delight
plants.note: low chill

plants.name: Carmel
plants.note: Excellent quality. Nut well sealed in the shell. Excellent pollinzer.

plants.name: Mission
plants.note: Late-blooming; productive tree. Hard shell, short kernel.

plants.name: Neplus Ultra
plants.note: Large, soft-shelled nut. Long, flat kernel. Good pollenizer.

plants.name: Nonpareil
plants.note: The most popular paper-shelled cultivar. Interfruitful with Price, Mission, Carmel.

plants.name: Price
plants.note: Very similar to Nonpareil. A good pollenizer.
